stem: A 22-year-old client with a comminuted fracture of the right femur suddenly becomes confused and tachypneic 24 hours after admission. The nurse notes a petechial rash on the chest and neck. Complete the clinical bowtie.

causes.text: Release of fat globules from bone marrow

rationale.correct: FES is caused by marrow fat release (c1) and subsequent inflammatory injury (c2). Management is supportive: High-flow oxygen (a1) for ARDS-like symptoms and fluids (a2) to maintain perfusion. SpO2 (p1) and Mental status (p2) are the key trackers of deterioration.
rationale.incorrect: Heparin (a3) is for blood clots, not fat emboli. Fasciotomy (a4) is for compartment syndrome.

clinicalPearls: Petechiae across the chest is the pathognomonic sign that distinguishes FES from PE.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that fat emboli are NOT blood clots; anticoagulants do not help and may increase bleeding risk.

mnemonic.title: FES
mnemonic.expansion:
F = Fat
E = Embolism
S = Syndrome

Key Actions: Administer high-flow oxygen; Initiate IV fluid resuscitation
Key Monitoring: Oxygen saturation (SpO2); Mental status (GCS)

reviewUnits.heading: Fat Embolism
reviewUnits.body: FES occurs in 1-3% of long bone fractures.
